Award.AwardTitle: Cell Mechanics and Protein Mobility during Neoplastic Transformation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary research objective of this grant is to advance the fundamental understanding of the different physical and mechanical properties of cells as they advance through different stages of neoplastic transformation from normal to the metastatic state. Since recent reports indicate there is significant ambiguity about how these properties change for different cancer cells, the investigators plan to measure these properties for a single line of cells, and to determine whether the changes vary for different cellular components: i.e. whether the change in physical properties is due to a change in the cytoskeleton, the cell membrane, the cytoplasm, or a combination of these elements. Measurements using a wide array of techniques from physics and cellular biology will be applied to the different cellular structures. In addition, the investigators will create a biophysical computer model that brings together all measurements to account for the observed variations in physical properties at each state of neoplastic transformation.

This work will help to establish and disseminate new protocols and techniques for determining the differences in physical properties between cancerous and noncancerous cells. A team of physicists and biologists will train graduate and undergraduate students to work in this highly interdisciplinary field. Particular emphasis will be given to the education of minorities, through the connections to the MARC U* STAR programs of NC A&T University and Winston-Salem State University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to determine how select mechanical properties of human breast cells change as they undergo four stages of neoplastic transformation: 1) noncancerous, 2) immortal, 3) tumorigenic, and 4) metastatic. Immortal cells are the first stage of being compromised by having the natural programmed cell death instruction set turned off. Tumorigenic cells are a more advanced stage in which the cells would form tumors if injected under the skin of mice. Metastatic cells can spread cancer to new locations in the human body.

 We studied these cells using different techniques to measure stiffness on a large scale (whole cell) and on a small scale (on a microscopic scale inside the cell). Large scale stiffness measurements were performed with an atomic force microscope (AFM - see figure).  Here, a 5.3 um bead, which is attached to the end of a small flexible cantilever, was pressed onto each cell's surface. The cantilever deflection was converted into a stiffness measurement of the cell. Small scale measurements of stiffness involved two methods: 1) tracking small, natural spherical particles, called organelles, inside cells and 2) measuring the movement of protein molecules, which are much smaller than organelles, inside cells. The tracking data could be converted into a measurement of the stiffness of the regions inside the cell. The range of our measurements is useful because it reports the mechanical properties of the cells on very different size scales, and so they help to give a complete picture of how cancer affects these properties on a broad range of size scales.

Interesting results from the AFM measurements on whole cell stiffness for breast cancer cells were that cell stiffness varied depending on the cancer stage (cells get less stiff as cancer progresses), and also on the micro-environment surrounding the cell. For example, noncancerous cells inside a cluster of cells are stiffer than peripheral cells, which are stiffer than isolated cells. However, the stiffness of cancer cells is less sensitive to the microenvironment than normal cells. Another set of interesting results were obtained by using the same microscope to study bone marrow cancer cells to understand mechanisms that may explain how multiple myeloma tumors are initiated, how they progress, and metastasize, and why this malignancy remains incurable and relapses due to intrinsic or acquired drug resistance. We found that the stiffness of bone marrow cells of multiple myeloma patients increased when they interacted with myeloma cells. We investigated the mechanism for this interaction and found that a specific protein and cell-receptor pair played an important role in signaling the stiffness changes to the bone marrow cells of multiple myeloma patients. Such results help us to understand the processes that are occurring in cellular signaling, and can possibly help in knowing where to focus on disrupting such signaling in order to develop better cancer therapeutics in the future.

On the small scale, by analyzing the organelle tracking data, we also found that cancer cells were softer than noncancerous cells on the microscopic scale. Internally, the cells became much softer as a result of cancer - softer to an even greater extent than they became on the larger scale. So the results on both scales were consistent with each other, but the size of the changes were significantly larger on the small scale.

Finally, another important result of this research was the establishment of reference standards and the comparison of the stiffness of a fairly large number of different hydrogels that are used as scaffolds for tissue engineering. Hydrogels are composed of a mix of fibers, water, and other chemicals that can support cells, and allow cells seeded in them to potentially form useful human tissues.
